entry.title: Re: 3 more videos on integrating SAP Build Apps with DMS
entry.content:
I don't think DMS was ever available in trial. Integration Option is available in free tier.

Document AI seems to be a new name for Document Extraction, uploading a document and extract the information inside it. DMS is just about having a repository for your documents.

entry.title: Re: How to Approve/Reject Task via API in SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
@nayak_aj There is an API under Workflow Definitions to retrieve the "model" of a workflow.

I created a custom button along with the standard submit button. The button's display name is CustomButton and its identifier is button1. 

If I run the model API for this process, in part I get this, where I can see the display name and the identifier of the button.

Is that what you needed?

P.S.: Sorry for the delay in responding üò∏

entry.title: Triggering Process in Shared Environment from SAP Build Apps - Better Solution üò∏
entry.content:
In my previous blog post Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps,  I showed you how to trigger from SAP Build Apps a process that was deployed to a shared environment  -- using HTTP Destination Request instead of Processes flow functions.

Though I thought it was pretty easy -- and I liked it because I could control the API call and see what was going on under the hood -- it still required me to know the APIs as well as to give up on some of the cool SAP Build Apps capabilities that come with the Processes flow functions (like automatic generation of schemas from inputs/outputs of a process).

Thanks to @KuroKen, I discovered a better way, who commented on my original post.

At first I struggled to get the solution to work, even though I was assured it worked. But as usual, the struggling was good and revealed all kinds of additional nuances about the system (see Issues below). After 2 weeks of study, here's my explanation of this solution.

The Problem (reminder)

SAP Build Apps has a wonderful set of flow functions that makes it easy to trigger processes (and run other SAP Build Process Automation APIs). 

But the problem is that they were developed before SAP Build environments was a big thing, and certainly before the Public environment was deprecated. The API to trigger a process in a shared environment requires a query parameter specifying the environment, but the flow functions do not include this parameter and therefore the flow function can only trigger Public processes, which as we said are deprecated.

üôÄ

The Solution

Well, it is pretty simple -- don't require the query parameter.

But how?

When creating the SAP Build Process Automation instance in the SAP BTP cockpit, you can add a small configuration  that will assign that instance to a specific shared environment so you will not have to pass the environment name when you call the API.

To set up SAP Build Process Automation, you need to create an instance of the service. In the cockpit click Create.

You select SAP Build Process Automation, and select the standard instance plan. 

Instead of clicking Create, click Next so you can add a configuration to specify a shared environment to connect to this instance. In the dialog, you enter an environment ID and an API key with rights to trigger processes and more.

The following is the dialog where you post your configuration:

The following is an example of the JSON to set (you need to replace with your own environment ID and API key):

{
    "environmentId": "salesgroup",
    "apiKey": "fPdjgABCD-wZUckjh-c6e2wFyU3SgL"
}

 If you already have an instance, you can run Update and then supply the JSON.

Some of this process is described here: https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/update-service-instance

Environment ID

The environment ID can be found when you go to Control Tower and open your environment, under Identifier.

API Key

Within the environment, you can go to the API Keys tab and create a new API key.

For the key you must give it enough scope for triggering processes, specifically the environment_read, trigger_read and trigger_execute scopes.

 

How You Trigger Process from SAP Build Apps

Now that we have overcome the problem with shared environments, here's a quick review of how to trigger a process from SAP Build Apps.

  1. Publish your deployed process project.
  2.  In SAP Build Apps, go to Integrations > Add Integration > Library, and select the process you want to expose from within the deployed project (which should appear since the project was published). Click Enable Process. 
  3. In the logic canvas (perhaps in response to a button), drag in a Processes > Trigger Process flow function. 
  4. In the flow function, specify the process to trigger and the inputs for the process.

 

Issues

The main issue was that I was using a destination with OAuth2JWTBearer (user authentication). The above works currently only for OAuth2ClientCredentials. So when @KuroKen explained his solution, I didn't understand because it didn't work for me, and he must of thought I was incompetent or crazy.

I contacted development and they confirmed that I was not crazy, that in fact there was a bug -- the client credentials and user token authentication flows used different flows and the one for user tokens had a bug. My understanding is that that bug was fixed and is awaiting deployment. As always,, no guarantees

Potential pitfall

This solution works like a charm, and restores all the great capabilities of SAP Build Apps flow functions. And as long as long as there are only a few environments, it should work pretty well.

But let's say I have 3 environments, and I create 3 instances of SAP Build Process Automation, each will require its own destination to define the connection from SAP Build Apps. But SAP Build Apps assumes the name of the destination is sap_process_automation_service_user_access. So in a  case where I want to trigger processes in different environments from my app, I think I would have a problem -- though I do not know how common a use case that would be.

I am told that there is no cost or performance issue for creating multiple instances, so that is good.

I assume that I can override the configuration by sending the query parameter for another environment, but I have not tested this.

Hope this helps,

üò∏

entry.title: Re: SAP Build - Get Record fetches data but properties ar...
entry.content: If you use the classic REST with Destination for fetching your data, you can use the Response Mapper to modify the response before it gets into the UI or data variable.

entry.title: Re: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content: @KuroKen The reason it did not work for me is because there is a bug that prevents doing your solution with user token exchange. I believe this will get fixed sometime soon. That was the source of our confusion. üò∏

entry.title: Re: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
@Dominar 

  • Did you send an API key? https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/add-api-keys?locale=en-US
  • Did you send the API key as a header with the proper key - irpa-api-key?
  • Is the API key for the environment you are trying to trigger? 
  • Does it have the the scope required to trigger processes? https://help.sap.com/docs/build-process-automation/sap-build-process-automation/api-keys?locale=en-US

P.S.: When sending questions, it helps to see screenshots and get the full set up üò∏

entry.title: Re: Triggering Process in Shared Environments from SAP Build Apps
entry.content:
1) I need more information here: Which project does this appear? Screenshot? What are you executing at that moment? How are you displaying/seeing the message -- Alert box, developer tools, SAP Build Monitoring?

2) That's a real technical message I've never seen before.

I just wrote on LinkedIn how great the community is, and it is. But it also can be infuriating -- me and everyone here (almost) has jobs, families, hobbies -- we want to help but to make a context switch and then to understand where you are in your debugging is nearly impossible, and given that you are on your own network, perhaps controlled by your company's IT, going through how many routers and firewalls, with a SAP BTP commercial model of who knows what, using who knows what service plan, with instances and destinations set up in myriad possible ways, and with no access to see them, and with no debugging information to understand where is the problem (SAP Build Apps, SAP Build Process Automation, destination configuration, integration configuration, browser, network, Build Apps user interface) and not knowing where these messages appear (SAP Build Monitoring tab for an instance, popup in Build Apps, in Developer Tools during API call, perhaps when testing a destination in the SAP BTP cockpit) -- it's all very difficult, and we and the rest of the community are not support but people who curious and very much want to help people.

I don't mean to rant on you -- this is something I've been thinking about a long time and has been frustrating me for a long time, perhaps since 2004 and the days of SDN (at the risk of aging me) üò∏

entry.title: üü° The New Developer Community
entry.content:
Take a tour of the new Developer area of the community, where you can find resources for developers and correspond with your developer peers about all issues related to SAP development: ABAP, CAP, UI5, Fiori, Node.JS, SAP Build, AI and more.

Speaker:

  • Anne Kathrine Petteroe, SAP Community

entry.title: üü° Take the Next Step in Your Career and Master an SAP Certification
entry.content:
Join this session with Diana Roesner, Head of Certification Transformation at SAP, to get practical tips to get certified with SAP, and hear about the future of certifications. You will also hear from one of our mentors about their own experience getting certified.

Speakers:

  • Diana Alexandra R√∂sner, SAP
  • Geert-Jan Klaps, TheValueChain 

Diana is the Head of Certification Transformation at SAP. In this role, she leads the strategic evolution of SAP‚Äôs global certification program, aiming to expand its reach and strengthen its relevance in the digital learning ecosystem. With a strong background in product enablement, go-to-market strategy, and communications, Diana R√∂sner previously led the Product Enablement for SAP Build.

Geert-Jan has a very strong technical background (+14 years of experience). As Innovation Architect and SAP Mentor, he's focusing on the latest SAP (cloud) technologies, with a special focus on technical architecture and development for partner multitenant solutions on top of SAP Business Technology Platform.

entry.title: üü° How to Interview for an SAP Tech Job
entry.content:
Landing your next SAP role takes more than just knowing your way around ABAP, CAP, or Fiori. In this fast-paced, practical session, we‚Äôll talk about how to prepare for SAP-focused interviews‚Äîfrom understanding the role‚Äôs tech stack to handling scenario questions and showcasing your project experience. You‚Äôll learn what hiring managers are really looking for, common mistakes to avoid, and how to stand out in a competitive field. Whether you‚Äôre early in your SAP career or a seasoned pro eyeing your next move, you‚Äôll leave with clear, actionable tips to help you ace the interview.

Speaker,

  • Thomas Jung, SAP

I‚Äôve spent nearly 30 years in SAP‚Äîstarting as an ABAP developer and now leading SAP‚Äôs Developer Advocacy team. My mission is simple: help developers cut through the noise and actually build things. The Dev Advocates create tutorials, blog posts, videos, and sample code, and meet developers at events worldwide. If you‚Äôre looking to level up your SAP skills or make sense of the latest tools, let‚Äôs talk. I‚Äôll bring the coffee.

entry.title: üü° Introducing the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt üî®ü™ô ... COMING SOON
entry.content:
Welcome to the Devtoberfest Scavenger Hunt, a chase around important SAP developer-related tools/sites, a challenge to construct a secret phrase, and a chance to win 1000s of points toward the Devtoberfest grand prize.

The hunt officially starts Sept. 25, with the release of the first clue during that day's SAP Developer News, and you have until the end of Devtoberfest, Oct. 24, to complete it.

To get all the clues make sure to SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

Learn more about the  entire Devtoberfest event in @KevinR's post Devtoberfest 2025 Welcome!.

What you need to find

We have hidden a special phrase, which you need to figure out using the clues from several missions, described in the next section. Along your journey you will do the following:

  1. Visit about 10 different locations related to SAP developers, mostly web sites that are designed to help you in your daily SAP development.
  2. At each location, you will discover a set of hexadecimal digits.
  3. Concatenate the digits together (in the order of the missions) to get one, 37-digit hexadecimal number.
  4. Multiply that hexadecimal number by another secret number, for which we will give a clue.
  5. Take the resulting 38-digit hexadecimal product, and convert it into the secret phrase, using each pair of digits as values for ASCII characters.
  6. Enter the phrase, exactly (case-sensitive, no extra spaces), into the Scavenger Hunt tutorial.‚Äå

Not until the SAP Developer News of Oct. 16 will you have all the pieces to be able to complete the phrase. 

Example Hunt

As an example of what you will have to do, here's a short sample hunt (just a warm-up, no points will be earned). Each mission is independent of the other.

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
17

SAP Developers YouTube Channel

Go to our SAP Developer YouTube channel. 

Open @Rekha_DR's video "SAP Build Process Automation (Part 1): Build your very first process". Watch it and find the secret 7-digit hexadecimal number in one of the info cards.

You can also see the hex digits in the description.

26SAP Community

Inside this blog post, use the Developer Tools on your browser to inspect the words "SAP Community" in the cell immediately to the left (in this very table) and find the 6-digit RGB ASCII code for the color of the text. 

3None (directly) 

Concatenate the 2 sets of hexadecimal digits (13 in all), in order, and multiply the resulting hexadecimal number by the number of original SAP founders (you can easily find the number on the SAP Wikipedia page).

Convert the resulting hexadecimal number into a phrase, converting each pair of digits into a character using ASCII codes.

üëâIn this blog post, post a comment/picture about the phrase -- but NOT the phrase itself  (like your experiences with or opinion about the phrase, or a picture of something belonging to you that reminds you of the phrase). You won't get any points, but it will be fun and you will be ready for the real scavenger hunt. If you have any trouble with this example hunt, post in the comments.

REMINDER: The above is just an example of how the real scavenger hunt will work. The real scavenger hunt instructions will be described in the rest of this blog post, as clues become available.

 

The (real) hunt

Below are the instructions for finding the hexadecimal digits for the actual scavenger hunt. We will release clues as follows:

  • In the SAP Developer News of Sept. 25, Oct. 2, Oct. 9, and Oct. 16.
  • In this blog each Monday during the first 3 weeks of Devtoberfest.

üëâTo be notified when a new clue is released, SUBSCRIBE TO THIS POST!!

‚Äå When you find the secret phase, just enter it into this Devtoberfest tutorial.

To guide you, we have created a second tutorial -- you do not have to use it, nor do you get any points from it. But you can enter the 1 to 6 digits from each mission to check if you received the correct digits for that mission.

Here are your missions 

MissionNo. DigitsSAP Web PropertyInstructions
12

SAP Developer News

The Developer News comes out each Thursday with the latest about ABAP, CAP, BTP, SAP Build, UI5, Fiori, AI, and all your favorite SAP developer topics. All delivered by some of your favorite Developer Advocates, like DJ, Shilpa Shankar, Thomas Jung, Antonio Maradiaga, Nora von Thenen and the rest of the gang.

Most episodes about 5 minutes. Also available as a Podcast.

Watch the Developer News of Sept. 25
26 To be released Sept. 29
34 To be released Sept. 29
42 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 2
54 To be released Oct. 6
66 To be released Oct. 6
76 Watch the Developer News of Oct. 9
86 To be released Oct. 13
91 To be released Oct. 13
10None (directly) Watch the Developer News of Oct. 16

Good luck!

üò∏
